subject: probability
title: General Normal Distribution
contentHtml:
The general normal distribution is a fundamental concept in probability theory that describes continuous random variables with mean μ and variance σ².

In this context, 'normal' refers to the bell-shaped curve of the distribution, which is symmetric around the mean and has a finite variance.
intuition: The general normal distribution is a powerful tool for modeling real-world phenomena, as it can be used to describe continuous data that follows a bell-shaped curve. This concept is crucial in many fields, including machine learning and artificial intelligence.
realWorldApplications: Modeling human height or weight distributions
commonMistakes: Assuming the normal distribution only applies to discrete variables
Not considering the importance of standardization

subject: probability
title: General Normal Distribution
contentHtml:
The general normal distribution is a fundamental concept in probability theory that describes continuous random variables with a mean μ and variance σ².

It's characterized by its bell-shaped curve, where most values cluster around the mean, and fewer values are found at the extremes.
intuition: The normal distribution is like a 'bell-curve' that shows how likely different values are to occur. Most values cluster around the mean, and fewer values are found at the extremes.
realWorldApplications: In machine learning, the normal distribution is often used as a prior for Gaussian mixture models.
commonMistakes: Not understanding that σ² represents the variance, not just the standard deviation

subject: probability
title: General Normal Distribution
contentHtml:
The general normal distribution is a fundamental concept in probability theory that describes continuous random variables with mean μ and variance σ².

It's characterized by its bell-shaped curve, which is symmetric around the mean and has most of its values clustered near the mean.
intuition: The general normal distribution is a great way to model real-world phenomena that are inherently uncertain, like human heights or stock prices. It's also a key component in many machine learning algorithms, such as Gaussian mixture models and Kalman filters.
commonMistakes: Assuming the normal distribution is only used for discrete variables
Not understanding the importance of standardization
